header.title: How to Summons the 72 Names of God

central_thesis: The book presents a simple, ritualistic method for practitioners to visibly summon and communicate with the 'spirit energies' of the 72 Names of God, derived from Kabbalah, to manifest desires related to money, health, love, psychic abilities, and information. The author claims the rituals are effective regardless of the practitioner's belief.

structure_content.summary: Outlines the book's purpose: to teach a simple yet powerful ritual to summon and communicate with the 72 Names of God for visible appearance and fulfillment of desires. It mentions the Kabbalistic origin of the names from the Book of Exodus and the minimal tools required.

structure_content.chapter_title: I. The 72 Names of God Summoning Ritual
structure_content.summary: Provides step-by-step instructions for setting up the ritual space ('Temple Set Up'), performing the 'Opening Rituals' involving bell ringing and vibrating the 72 Names, engaging in 'Spirit Communication' through an evocation formula and trance induction, and concluding with 'Closing Rituals' and post-ritual recording of experiences.
This section lists the 72 Names of God, presented with their Hebrew characters and transliterated English spellings, serving as a catalog for practitioners to select specific names for their rituals.

structure_content.chapter_title: III. The 72 Names of God Writing Journal
structure_content.summary: This chapter is designated as a journal for recording ritual experiences, communications with spirits, and observations of signs and messages received in the days following the ritual.

key_concepts.definition: Hidden names found in the Kabbalistic tradition, derived from the Book of Exodus, described as powerful vibrations representing 'spirit energies' of God that can be summoned for various requests.
The core magical act of invoking a specific Name of God to 'visibly appear' before the practitioner, as instructed in the ritual, to answer requests and fulfill desires.
The energetic technique of speaking or chanting the Names of God, specifically requiring each name to be vibrated three times, with one second per syllable, to activate its 'powerful vibrations'.
The process of closing one's eyes after evocation, asking questions, and recording all 'feelings, dreams, thoughts and ideas, songs and sounds' as answers from the invoked spirit/energy.
A state induced by counting down from 1 to 15 while visualizing descending in an elevator, used to facilitate communication with the summoned entity during the ritual.
A personal record-keeping tool to document the ritual process, outcomes, and any subsequent signs or messages received, crucial for integrating magical experiences.

practical_system.description: The book outlines a simplified, practical system for summoning the 'spirit energies' associated with the 72 Names of God to visible appearance and communication. The system emphasizes direct results, requiring minimal tools and preparation, and explicitly states that belief in the rituals is not necessary for their efficacy.
tools: The 72 Names of God Writing Journal (for recording results)
rituals: Temple Set Up: Practitioner wears a robe (optional), holds a wand (optional), sets up an altar with a cloth, bell, lit candles, sandalwood incense, and creates a rope circle around themselves and the altar, facing East.
Request Formulation: The practitioner decides on a specific Name of God and writes down their desired request.
Opening Ritual: The practitioner rings a bell and declares, 'this temple is now open'.
Opening Prayer/Vibration: All 72 Names of God are vibrated three times each, with one second spent on each syllable, in numerical order from 1 to 72.

Spirit Communication: The practitioner says an evocation formula three times: 'I summon and evoke thee, (name of God), to visibly appear before me and answer my request of (request).' This is followed by a trance induction (counting down 1 to 15 while visualizing descending in an elevator). With eyes closed, the practitioner asks questions and records all felt, heard, thought, and seen answers into a digital recorder.

Closing Ritual: The practitioner issues a 'License to Depart' saying, 'I thank thee, (name of God), this ritual is now done. All forces, Entities and Energies shall go about their business until again I call. In the Ultimate Name, go in peace to do my bidding. Harm nobody and none and nothing that I have, that I like and love. So mote it be.'
Temple Closure: The practitioner rings the bell and declares, 'this temple is now closed'.

Post-Ritual Integration: The practitioner records the ritual and results in a journal (The Book of Shadows/Writing Journal) and listens to the digital recorder. In the following days, they pay attention to feelings, dreams, thoughts, ideas, songs, and sounds as messages from the spirits.
Meditation: For general mind, body, and spirit recharge, one can simply vibrate each of the 72 Names of God three times each.

relevant_quotes.text: This book is a simple yet incredibly powerful way to summons The 72 Names of God and to easily communicate with these spirits or energies of God while they are visibly in front of you.
The 72 Names of God, which give off powerful vibrations, are the hidden names Kabbalah has found in the book of Exodus and were given to the Israelites to use in order to cross the Red Sea.
Say this 3 times: 'I summon and evoke thee, (name of God), to visibly appear before me and answer my request of (request).'
To communicate with the spirits of God close your eyes and ask a question(s) and then say into the recorder what you feel, hear, think and see as your answer from the spirit.
This text deals with astral and physical forces that can be dangerous if misused or used carelessly.

critical_analysis.relevance: Kuriakos's 'How to Summons the 72 Names of God' offers a highly simplified and direct approach to Kabbalistic evocation, contrasting with more complex and theoretically dense traditional grimoire practices. Its primary innovation lies in reducing a historically intricate system to a '10-minute' ritual requiring minimal specialized knowledge or belief, aimed at immediate and tangible results. While traditional Kabbalah emphasizes spiritual growth and understanding divine emanations, this work reorients the 72 Names towards practical, results-oriented 'bidding' for material and psychic gains, positioning itself within the modern utilitarian magick paradigm. The claim of 'visible appearance' and requiring no belief are significant, setting it apart from many Western Esoteric traditions that often stress years of preparatory work, moral rectitude, and developed spiritual sight. It attempts to democratize access to a powerful mystical tradition, making it accessible to those who might otherwise be intimidated by scholarly or complex ritual prerequisites.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is individuals new to occult or magical practices, particularly those interested in Kabbalistic traditions but seeking a highly accessible, streamlined, and results-focused system. It appeals to practitioners of Chaos Magic or pragmatic occultists who prioritize efficacy and personal experience over adherence to rigid dogmas or extensive theoretical study. The book also targets individuals seeking immediate solutions to personal problems (money, health, love) through spiritual means, who may not have a background in esotericism. The explicit 'Caveat' suggests an audience expected to exercise personal responsibility, implying some awareness of the potential dangers associated with engaging with 'astral and physical forces'.
